pass.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to come up to a particular place, person, or object and go past them
pass.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The crowd parted to let the truck pass.
He gave me a smile as he passed.
We passed a group of students outside the theatre.
I pass the sports centre on the way to work.
pass.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to go or travel along or through a place
pass.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He passed along the corridor to a small room at the back of the building.
We passed through the gates into a courtyard behind.
We were just passing through (=travelling through a place) and thought we’d drop in to see you.
pass.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to put something around, through, or across something else
pass.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: He passed the rope carefully around the post.
pass.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a road, river, or railway line that passes a place goes through or near the place
pass.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: The road passes right through the town centre.
The main railway line passes just north of Manchester.
pass.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to hold something in your hand and give it to someone else
pass.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Can you pass me that bag by your feet?
She passed a cup of tea to the headmaster.
I passed the note back to her.
pass.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to give information or a job to another person so that they can deal with it
pass.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: I’ll pass the information on to our sales department.
They’ve passed the enquiry over to the police.
pass.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: if time passes, it goes by
pass.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: She became more ambitious as the years passed.
They sat in silence while the minutes passed.
Hardly a day passes without more bad news about the economy  (=there is bad news almost every day).
pass.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: if you pass time or pass your life in a particular way, you spend it in that way
pass.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: We passed the winter pleasantly enough.
We played cards to pass the time (=to help us stop feeling bored).
pass.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to succeed in an examination or test
pass.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Did you pass all your exams?
He hasn’t passed his driving test yet.
She passed with flying colours (=got very high marks).
pass.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to officially decide that someone has succeeded in an examination or test
pass.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: The examiners will only pass you if they feel that you have done the work properly.
pass.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to officially accept a law or proposal, especially by voting
pass.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Plans to extend the hotel have now been passed.
The motion was passed by 16 votes to 11.
The government has passed new legislation to protect consumers.
The United Nations Security Council has passed a resolution asking the two countries to resume peace negotiations.
The first Transport Act was passed in 1907.
pass.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: if a law or proposal passes an official group, it is officially accepted by that group
pass.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: The bill failed to pass the House of Representatives.
pass.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: if something passes between people, they speak to each other or do something together
pass.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: Please say nothing of what has passed here today.
A glance of recognition passed between them.
pass.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: After a couple of hours the storm passed.
The feeling of sickness soon passed.
pass.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: to kick, throw, or hit a ball to a member of your own team during a game
pass.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: He passed to Beckham on the edge of the penalty area.
Are you allowed to pass the ball back to the goalkeeper?
pass.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: to become more than a particular number or amount
pass.translation[0].definitions[15].exam: The number of unemployed has passed the two million mark for the first time.
pass.translation[0].definitions[16].defi: to change from being controlled or owned by one person to being controlled or owned by someone else
pass.translation[0].definitions[16].exam: Control of these services has now passed into the hands of the local authorities.
The land will pass to my son when I die.
pass.translation[0].definitions[17].defi: to change from one state or condition into another
pass.translation[0].definitions[17].exam: The chemical passes from a liquid to a solid state during the cooling process.
pass.translation[0].definitions[18].defi: to give no answer to a question because you do not know the answer
pass.translation[0].definitions[19].defi: to not accept an invitation or offer
pass.translation[0].definitions[19].exam: I’m afraid I’ll have to pass on that offer of coffee.
pass.translation[0].definitions[20].defi: to let out a waste substance from your bladder or bowels
pass.translation[0].definitions[20].exam: See your doctor immediately if you pass any blood.
He was having difficulty passing water (=letting out urine).
pass.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: an official piece of paper which shows that you are allowed to enter a building or travel on something without paying
pass.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: They issued us with free passes to the theatre.
You can buy a cheap one-day bus pass.
pass.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a successful result in an examination
pass.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: You will need at least three passes to get onto the course.
The pass mark (=the mark you need to be successful) is 55%.
Did you get a pass in English?
pass.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: when you kick, throw, or hit a ball to another member of your team during a game
pass.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: That was a brilliant pass by Holden.
pass.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a high road or path that goes between mountains to the other side
pass.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: one part of a process that involves dealing with the whole of a group or thing several times
pass.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: On the first pass we eliminated all the candidates who didn’t have the right experience.
pass.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: a movement in which an aircraft flies once over a place which it is attacking
pass.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if an official group passes a law, proposal etc, or it passes that group, it is accepted by them, especially by voting
pass.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Shareholders of Fibreboard Corp. narrowly passed a measure doubling the shares in the company’s employee stock option plan.
Congress this year will pass a bill giving banks permission to open branches nationwide.
Legislation similar to the anti-price-fixing bill passed the Senate last month.
pass.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to succeed in an examination, test etc
pass.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Policyholders must pass a medical to qualify for lower insurance rates.
How could faulty valves have passed the inspections?
pass.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to give someone a piece of information, knowledge, a message etc that has been received from someone else
pass.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: The transmitters pass phone calls to and from cellular phones.
Firms can’t pass information onto third parties until it is released by the stockmarket’s own news service.
Employees were suspected of passing on confidential documents.
pass.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: to go officially from one person’s control or ownership to someone else’s
pass.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: Sales will be recognised when title  (=ownership) passes or when the contract is signed.
The property had passed to him after his father’s death.
pass.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: to fail to pay the DIVIDEND on a share (=the part of the profit paid to shareholders) in a particular period of time, usually because of financial difficulties
pass.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: The steelwork group is passing its final dividend after profits plunged last year.
pass.translation[2].definitions[5].defin: if a particular date or time passes, or you pass it, it goes by and is in the past
pass.translation[2].definitions[5].examp: The IRS will permit an extension of time for certain actions even after the deadline has passed.
pass.translation[2].definitions[6].defin: to go above a particular amount, number or level, as a total gradually increases
pass.translation[2].definitions[6].examp: Aluminum prices passed $1 a pound last week, a rise of 43% since March.
Israel’s population passed the six million mark in 1999.
pass.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: a special document containing a person’s name and often their photograph, showing that they are allowed to enter a particular building, travel somewhere etc
pass.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Simply present your Executive Club card andboarding pass (=one that allows you to get on a plane) to receive a complimentary drink.
